title: CHED to halt field trips after Tanay crash
text:
CHED to halt field trips after Tanay crash By Kristian Javier (philstar.com)   1:03pm CHED Commissioner Prospero de Vera wants field trips suspended in response to the recent tragedy in Tanay. Philstar.com, File/ Prospero De Vera, Facebook 
MANILA, Philippines (2nd update; First published 9:39 a.m.) — The Commission on Higher Education on Tuesday announced that it will issue a moratorium on field trips and educational tours at the wake of the bus accident in Tanay, Rizal that killed 15 students. PhCHEd to issue a #moratorium on field trips and educational tours in light of recent events involving the death of students. 
— CHED Caraga (@CHEDCaraga) February 21, 2017 
Commissioner Prospero de Vera earlier called for the suspension of the school trips while investigation into a bus crash is ongoing. 
The suspension will cover all field trips and educational tours in all colleges and universities until the investigation is completed. 
Early Monday, a tourist bus carrying students from Bestlink College of the Philippines smashed into an electric post along a curved road in Barangay Sampaloc in Tanay on their way to medical and survival training at the Sacramento Adventure Camp as part of their National Service Training Program, an alternative program to the Reserve Officers' Training Corps.   
Fourteen students and the driver were killed, while 40 students were listed as injured, as of early Tuesday. 
READ: 15 dead in Tanay bus accident 
"I will request the Commission en banc today to immediately issue a directive to all higher education institutions so we can properly investigate this tragedy and review current policies covering field trips," De Vera said in a press statement on Tuesday. 
He added that it must also be determined if higher education institutions comply with safety guidelines and whether current policies on school trips protect the students adequately. 
CHED has instructed the school to submit an incident report immediately so that the commission can determine if regulations were violated. 
"The Tanay tragedy is a reminder that we must be very strict in regulating the use of public transport for school-sponsored trips," De Vera said. 
He added that while field trips are essential for students to learn, their safety must always be ensured. 
Quezon City Rep. Winnie Castelo has also called on a suspension of field trips and said schools that force students to join educational tours and trips should close down. A village official looks at the wreckage of a bus that lost its brakes and killed more than a dozen passengers on a downhill road in Tanay, Rizal on Monday Feb. 20, 2017. Town officials say the victims, most of them college students on a camping trip, were killed when their rented bus lost its brakes on a downhill road and slammed into a post. AP/Aaron Favila Higher Education Commissioner Popoy De Vera speaks to media on the recent Tanay bus accident on Tuesday, Feb. 22, 2016. CHED/Released 
On August 19, 2014, seven tourism students from Bulacan State University drowned as they were crossing Madlum River to go to the Madlum Cave in San Miguel, Bulacan. 
In 2013, Camiguin Rep. Pedro Romualdo urged CHED and the Department of Education to ban compulsory field trips, especially to destinations far away due to safety concerns after seven died when a bus collided with a 14-wheeler truck along the Marcos Highway in Benguet. 
"I don’t see the wisdom of requiring field trips. During our time, we did not have field trips, but we managed to learn a lot in school," Romualdo said.
